title: Wrong line number (code location) reported in failing tests
body:
## Description
It seems in some cases the extra lines in other files are added to the line number of a failing test. Not sure if this is just an issue on my system, VS or with Catch. Read the below sample to better understand the issue.


### Steps to reproduce
In Visual Studio 2015 I created empty C++ project and copied the catch.hpp file to the source folder and then created three new files:
main.cpp
```
#define CATCH_CONFIG_MAIN
#include "catch.hpp"
```

test1.cpp
```
#include "catch.hpp"
// Notice the empty lines below

// This comment also adds one to the test2.cpp failing test cases reported line number


TEST_CASE("test1", "") {
	REQUIRE(1 == 1);
}
```

test2.cpp
```
#include "catch.hpp"

TEST_CASE("test2", "") {
	REQUIRE(1 == 2);
}
```


Outcome
```
test2
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
test2.cpp(3)
...............................................................................
test2.cpp(8): FAILED:
  REQUIRE( 1 == 2 )

===============================================================================
test cases: 2 | 1 passed | 1 failed
assertions: 2 | 1 passed | 1 failed
```

I would expect test2.cpp(8) to be test2.cpp(4).

I also noticed that if I add a test0.cpp with same content as test2.cpp except TEST_CASE name changed to test0 then it again works as expected.

Note that I also saw in some cases that the test2.cpp(3) line was wrong too, but this simplified sample doesn't demonstrate that.


### Extra information
* Catch version: **Catch v1.8.1**
* Operating System: **Windows 7 x64**
* Compiler+version: **MS Visual Studio 2015 VC++**
